Award.AwardTitle: Genetic, molecular, and biochemical analysis of RNA splicing factors critical for maize endosperm development

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how plants process RNA to influence maize grain composition and quality. All organisms express genes by transcribing their DNA into RNA, with most RNA molecules getting translated into protein. In plants, animals, and fungi, genes that code for proteins typically have a modular structure made up of exons, which are needed to express a protein, and introns, which need to be removed by RNA splicing factors. This project will examine the role of four RNA splicing factors in removing introns from genes needed to develop a maize kernel. The research will integrate genetic, molecular, genomic, and biochemical approaches to define functional networks of genes influenced by these splicing factors and may identify genes that could be used to improve seed set or grain-fill in crop plants. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students in biological research through multiple activities aimed at helping the students to develop into professional scientists.

Splicing of pre-mRNA is critical to expressing genes as phenotypes. However, the molecular mechanisms by which plant RNA splicing factors influence splice site selection and how alternative splicing influences plant phenotypes are largely unknown. There are significant gaps in knowledge about the target introns for individual splicing factors. It is not known how individual splicing factors influence splicing decisions to control the proteome and, ultimately, the phenotype of the plant. This project will focus on splicing factors with strong evidence for functional importance in maize seed development. RNA splicing events required for seed development will be identified in splicing factor mutants that cause seed defects. Reverse genetics analysis will determine the roles of a plant-specific putative splicing SR protein known to be expressed in seeds. Cell-type specific and direct targets of two RNA splicing factors critical to the maize endosperm will be identified. Integrating the data from the aims will elucidate mechanisms by which individual RNA splicing factors influence gene expression to differentiate endosperm cell types and ultimately influence multicellular phenotypes. Because seeds are the primary product of maize crops, understanding RNA splicing in seed development will both advance fundamental molecular biology and identify pathways and proteins for future crop improvement.

This award is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Plant Genome Research Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, both in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Plants and animals are eukaryotes or organisms with a nucleus in their cells. The nucleus separates the process of transcribing genes (DNA to RNA) from translating RNA to protein. This allowed the evolution of introns, which are segments of non-protein coding sequences that need to be removed from RNA prior to translation into protein. The removal of introns is known as RNA splicing and has been an essential part of eukaryotic gene expression for more than one billion years. 

This project studied RNA splicing in maize during seed development. Specifically, we found that endosperm cells require efficient RNA splicing of a small number of genes that contain minor introns. Minor introns are termed minor, because there are only a few hundred minor introns in the tens of thousands of genes in a typical eukaryote. Minor introns have also been lost in many eukaryotes, especially unicellular species. 

We discovered two genes required for minor intron splicing cause endosperm cells to get stuck in a proliferative, stem cell-like fate. The mutant endosperm cells divide excessively, similar to cancer cells. Surprisingly, the human version of one of these genes is required for blood stem cells to differentiate into their functional cell fates. Mutation of this minor splicing factor causes an anemia known as myeloid dysplasia and cancer known as Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Humans and corn evolved to have different cell types to support multicellular development independently, and this is an example of convergent evolution. The same RNA splicing pathway is used to promote cellular differentiation. We found that many orthologous genes have minor introns in both maize and human with many of the genes controlling cell division, which may explain this convergence. Biochemical studies in the project linked these two minor splicing genes with the major spliceosome, which gives some hint of how minor introns could be recognized in the cell. Specifically, the two RNA splicing factors we discovered in maize interact with RNA splicing factors in the major splicing complex.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project identified deep conservation of developmental mechanisms that are related to cereal grain productivity and human diseases caused by genetic mutations. The project also engaged diverse groups in science. Undergraduates from Oakland University, the University of Florida, and Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University (FAMU) performed many of the research aims. FAMU is a historically black university and the students mentored were from underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines. Most of the undergraduates presented their work at scientific conferences as first-author poster presenters and contributed as co-authors on peer-reviewed journal publications. Annual hands-on bioinformatics training workshops and seminars were conducted by the University of Florida co-investigators at Oakland University for the professional development of Oakland faculty and students. These activities also recruited Oakland students into Florida graduate programs. Data generated from the project was also integrated in upper-level undergraduate class settings to provide practical training to students in both web laboratory experiments and computational analysis. The vast majority of students trained during the project are pursuing additional training in STEM fields or are in STEM professions.
